question: [File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_ISS_VAL_BYTES] [Integer casting] Converting u16 constants to usize for use in Vec/slice operations - can narrowing casts on 16-bit platforms cause truncation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_EXTRA_FIELD_BYTES] [Arithmetic overflow] If MAX_EXTRA_FIELD_BYTES (u16) is used in arithmetic with other usize constants, can overflow occur on platforms with different pointer sizes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Stack overflow] Creating large G1/G2 points on the stack during VK construction - can this cause stack overflow on platforms with limited stack space? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Static: TEST_GROTH16_SETUP] [Memory leak] The Lazy static holds heap-allocated data for the entire process lifetime - in long-running validators, could this contribute to memory exhaustion? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [All constants] [const evaluation] The constants are const, not const fn - are there any runtime initialization costs that could be exploited for DoS? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Line 25-26] [Expression evaluation] The MAX_COMMITED_EPK_BYTES calculation happens at compile time - are there any ways to manipulate the compilation process to change this value? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Move semantics] The VerifyingKey is moved into PreparedVerifyingKey::from - can this leave stale VK data in memory that attackers could recover? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Unwrap safety] All .unwrap() calls assume point conversions succeed - if curve point validation changes in arkworks library updates, could these start panicking? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: g1_projective_str_to_affine] [Empty string handling] What happens if empty strings are passed for x or y coordinates - does parsing fail gracefully or panic? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: g2_projective_str_to_affine] [Unicode handling] Can Unicode lookalike digits (e.g., 'ùüò' instead of '0') in the coordinate strings bypass validation and create incorrect points? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Static: TEST_GROTH16_SETUP] [Initialization failure] If circuit_agnostic_setup_with_trapdoor fails, the .unwrap() panics - can attackers trigger this during validator startup to cause DoS? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Very large coordinates] The coordinate strings are extremely large numbers - can integer parsing overflow or cause excessive memory allocation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [All constants] [Boundary values] Are there any tests validating that these constants represent safe boundary values that don't cause overflow in downstream hash/proof operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_JWT_HEADER_B64_BYTES] [JWT header manipulation] Can an attacker craft JWT headers that are exactly 300 bytes base64-encoded but decode to malicious content that bypasses circuit validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_AUD_VAL_BYTES] [OIDC provider bypass] Can an attacker exploit the 120-byte aud limit to register a malicious OIDC provider whose URL fits in the limit but impersonates a trusted provider after truncation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_UID_VAL_BYTES] [Email address spoofing] With 330 bytes for uid_val, can attackers create email addresses with Unicode normalization issues that appear different but hash identically? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_UID_KEY_BYTES] [Custom claim injection] Can attackers exploit the 30-byte uid_key limit to inject custom JWT claim names that the circuit accepts but on-chain validation rejects? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_EXTRA_FIELD_BYTES] [Nonce replay] If extra_field contains nonce data and is limited to 350 bytes, can attackers exploit truncation to replay old nonces? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Constant: MAX_ISS_VAL_BYTES] [Issuer URL validation] The 120-byte issuer limit - can attackers craft URLs with path traversal or SSRF payloads that bypass circuit checks but exploit on-chain validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Circuit version pinning] The VK is from a specific circuit commit - if the circuit is updated for security fixes but VK isn't updated, can attackers exploit the old circuit vulnerabilities? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [VK rotation bypass] If governance rotates the on-chain VK but this hardcoded test VK is still referenced, can attackers exploit validators using outdated VK to validate invalid transactions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [All constants] [Constant modification] Since these are const items, can attackers exploit the fact that changing them requires code deployment rather than governance proposals to prevent emergency fixes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Function: prepared_vk_for_testing()] [Fallback VK] If the on-chain VK fetch fails, do validators fall back to this test VK, creating a security downgrade attack? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [All constants] [Hard fork risk] If these constants must be changed for a security fix, will it require a hard fork since changing them breaks address derivation compatibility? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/circuit_constants.rs] [Import: ark_bn254] [Library vulnerability] If ark_bn254 has vulnerabilities in its BN254 implementation, can attackers exploit these through the verification key operations? (High)
